page_analysis.text_content:
Accessory structure daylight plane (sides & rear)

Fig 25 Front elevation showing accessory-structure daylight plane at the side of the lot

Note: For accessory buildings near the rear & side lot lines, a hipped gable roof is often the best solution for complying with the accessory-structure daylight plane.

Fig 26 Side elevation showing accessory-structure daylight plane at the rear of the lot

Side

32

visual_elements.description: Front elevation diagram showing an accessory structure (appears to be a garage) with a hipped gable roof. Shows daylight plane angles marked as '3' on both sides, with measurements indicating '8' from average grade' and '24' max height of building'. Side lot lines are marked on both sides of the structure.

Side elevation diagram showing an accessory structure with daylight plane angle marked as '3'. Shows measurements of '8' from average grade' and '24' max height of building'. Rear lot line is marked at the bottom of the structure.
Small square diagram in bottom right showing directional arrows pointing to Front, Rear, and both Sides, with diagonal lines indicating the lot orientation.

additional_notes: Page number 32 appears at bottom left
Gray header bar spans width of page under main heading
Diagrams show technical elevation views with measurement annotations
Note section provides guidance on roof design for compliance

qualifiers.text: For accessory buildings near the rear & side lot lines

conditions.text: complying with the accessory-structure daylight plane

logical_relationships.expression: Building must meet both height measurement from grade and maximum height limit

execution_sequence.action: Evaluate if accessory building is near rear & side lot lines
Apply daylight plane requirements with height restrictions
